articles.headline: In Britain, a Soaring Deficit Lifts a Hawk
articles.snippet: George Osborne said voters would reward Conservatives at the polls if they spoke of dealing aggressively with the deficit.
articles.abstract: George Osborne said voters would reward Conservatives at the polls if they spoke of dealing aggressively with the deficit.
articles.lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER  It’s the deficit, stupid.

articles.headline: For Financial Planners, a Year of Tough Questions
articles.snippet: Five planners discuss the hard questions they faced from their worried clients, and some of the answers they gave.
articles.abstract: Five planners discuss the hard questions they faced from their worried clients, and some of the answers they gave.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you think you’ve had a hard time reckoning with your own finances in the last 18 months, try putting yourself in the shoes of the financial planners who’ve been answering to scores of unhappy clients.

articles.headline: In Mexican Drug War, Investigators Are Fearful
articles.snippet: Swamped with homicides, investigators cope with too little expertise and too much corruption, and they are targets themselves.
articles.abstract: Swamped with homicides, investigators cope with too little expertise and too much corruption, and they are targets themselves.
articles.lead_paragraph: CIUDAD JUÁREZ, Mexico  The hit men moved in on their target, shot him dead and then disappeared in a matter of seconds. It would have been a perfect case for José Ibarra Limón, one of this violent border city’s most dogged crime investigators  had he not been the victim.

articles.headline: $1.4 Trillion Deficit Complicates Stimulus Plans
articles.snippet: The White House faces a challenge in shrinking the fiscal gap, the largest relative to the size of the economy since 1945, while also taking steps to stimulate a slow recovery.
articles.abstract: The White House faces a challenge in shrinking the fiscal gap, the largest relative to the size of the economy since 1945, while also taking steps to stimulate a slow recovery.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration said Friday that the federal budget deficit for the fiscal year that just ended was $1.4 trillion, nearly a trillion dollars greater than the year before and the largest shortfall relative to the size of the economy since 1945.

articles.headline: The View From Inside a Depression
articles.snippet: A lawyer chronicling the Depression in the ’30s concluded that the only proper course was to “use your own judgment and do your own thinking.”
articles.abstract: A lawyer chronicling the Depression in the ’30s concluded that the only proper course was to “use your own judgment and do your own thinking.”
articles.lead_paragraph: “Dow at 10,000 as Crisis Ebbs”

articles.headline: Medicine’s Elusive Goal: A Safe Weight-Loss Drug
articles.snippet: Three small California companies are hoping to begin selling obesity drugs that could help treat one of America’s biggest and costliest health problems.
articles.abstract: Three small California companies are hoping to begin selling obesity drugs that could help treat one of America’s biggest and costliest health problems.
articles.lead_paragraph: Americans spent an estimated $59 billion last year fighting fat  on weight-loss programs, special foods, low-calorie soft drinks, appetite suppressants, gym memberships, diet books, exercise videos, even stomach-clamping surgery.

articles.headline: Hedge Fund Chief Is Charged With Fraud
articles.snippet: Six people were arrested on Friday in what prosecutors called the biggest insider trading scheme ever involving a hedge fund.
articles.abstract: Six people were arrested on Friday in what prosecutors called the biggest insider trading scheme ever involving a hedge fund.
articles.lead_paragraph: By all appearances, Raj Rajaratnam was a self-made billionaire, having built Galleon Group into a giant hedge fund with a specialty in technology companies.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Bailout Helps Fuel a New Era of Wall Street Wealth
articles.snippet: Efforts to stabilize the financial system also set the stage for financial titans to make fortunes in more lucrative areas than lending people money.
articles.abstract: Efforts to stabilize the financial system also set the stage for financial titans to make fortunes in more lucrative areas than lending people money.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even as the economy continues to struggle, much of Wall Street is minting money  and looking forward again to hefty bonuses.

articles.headline: Obama Drops Plan to Isolate Sudan Leaders
articles.snippet: An official said the White House’s policy would use a mix of “incentives and pressure” to end the human rights abuses that have burned Darfur into the American conscience.
articles.abstract: An official said the White House’s policy would use a mix of “incentives and pressure” to end the human rights abuses that have burned Darfur into the American conscience.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration has formulated a new policy for Sudan that proposes working with that country’s government, rather than isolating it as President Obama had pledged to do during his campaign.

articles.headline: Pakistan Aims Offensive at a Militant Stronghold
articles.snippet: Pakistan moved troops into the Taliban stronghold of South Waziristan in a long-anticipated ground offensive against the Qaeda-backed militants in treacherous terrain.
articles.abstract: Pakistan moved troops into the Taliban stronghold of South Waziristan in a long-anticipated ground offensive against the Qaeda-backed militants in treacherous terrain.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Pakistan moved thousands of troops into the militant stronghold of South Waziristan on Saturday, the army said, beginning a long-anticipated ground offensive against Al Qaeda and the Taliban in treacherous terrain that has stymied the army in the past.

articles.headline: Frustrated Liberal Lawmaker Balances Beliefs and Politics
articles.snippet: Earl Blumenauer, a liberal congressman from Portland, Ore., had faith that President Obama and Democrats in Congress would yield progressive advances. It has been, he says, “a hard landing.”
articles.abstract: Earl Blumenauer, a liberal congressman from Portland, Ore., had faith that President Obama and Democrats in Congress would yield progressive advances. It has been, he says, “a hard landing.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Representative Earl Blumenauer should be experiencing the most fulfilling days of his more than 35 years in public service.

articles.headline: A Lifeline Not Made in the U.S.A.
articles.snippet: With the economy in tatters, foreign companies are providing alternatives for American workers.
articles.abstract: With the economy in tatters, foreign companies are providing alternatives for American workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Millions of Americans work for foreign companies operating in the United States, but their stories are rarely told. As the country pulls out of a devastating recession, foreign employers could help revive the economy.

articles.headline: Don’t Let Exceptions Kill the Rule
articles.snippet: The House Financial Services Committee’s bill to regulate derivatives is a step in the right direction but has too many exceptions.
articles.abstract: The House Financial Services Committee’s bill to regulate derivatives is a step in the right direction but has too many exceptions.
articles.lead_paragraph: CONGRESS began the work of reforming our troubled financial system last week, and a bill aimed at regulating derivatives passed the House Financial Services Committee on Thursday.

articles.headline: 7 Months, 10 Days in Captivity
articles.snippet: A Times reporter, David Rohde, and two Afghan colleagues were kidnapped by the Taliban in 2008 and held for seven months in Pakistan. This is the first installment in a five-part series offering his account.
articles.abstract: A Times reporter, David Rohde, and two Afghan colleagues were kidnapped by the Taliban in 2008 and held for seven months in Pakistan. This is the first installment in a five-part series offering his account.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE car’s engine roared as the gunman punched the accelerator and we crossed into the open Afghan desert. I was seated in the back between two Afghan colleagues who were accompanying me on a reporting trip when armed men surrounded our car and took us hostage.

articles.headline: Forecast for Microsoft: Partly Cloudy
articles.snippet: From health care systems to cellphones, the C.E.O. Steven A. Ballmer wants Microsoft “to invent everything that’s important on the planet.”
articles.abstract: From health care systems to cellphones, the C.E.O. Steven A. Ballmer wants Microsoft “to invent everything that’s important on the planet.”
articles.lead_paragraph: REDMOND, Wash.

articles.headline: In Dollar’s Fall, Upside for U.S. Exports
articles.snippet: As economists, pundits and politicians debate the reasons for the dollar’s rapid fall, Robert Stevenson and his workers in Buffalo are watching the slide with glee.
articles.abstract: As economists, pundits and politicians debate the reasons for the dollar’s rapid fall, Robert Stevenson and his workers in Buffalo are watching the slide with glee.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS  As economists, pundits and politicians debate the reasons for the dollar’s rapid fall, Robert Stevenson and his workers in downtown Buffalo, N.Y., watch the slide with glee.

articles.headline: A Newsroom Subsidized? Minds Reel
articles.snippet: A report by Leonard Downie Jr., formerly of The Washington Post, sets forth a number of ways to pay for journalism. One of them is government money.
articles.abstract: A report by Leonard Downie Jr., formerly of The Washington Post, sets forth a number of ways to pay for journalism. One of them is government money.
articles.lead_paragraph: Those of us who work in traditional media have spent a fair amount of time wondering what part of the implosion in advertising revenue is cyclical (ad buying is suffering because of the recession) and what part is secular (we’re making horse buggies).

articles.headline: Inside the Islamic Emirate
articles.snippet: After being kidnapped in Afghanistan, David Rohde, a Times reporter, and two Afghan colleagues were moved into the tribal areas of Pakistan. The second installment in a series offering Mr. Rohde’s account of his captivity.
articles.abstract: After being kidnapped in Afghanistan, David Rohde, a Times reporter, and two Afghan colleagues were moved into the tribal areas of Pakistan. The second installment in a series offering Mr. Rohde’s account of his captivity.
articles.lead_paragraph: A YOUNG Taliban driver with shoulder-length hair got behind the wheel of the car. Glancing at me suspiciously in the rearview mirror, he started the engine and began driving down the left-hand side of the road.

articles.headline: Face-to-Face Socializing Starts With a Mobile Post
articles.snippet: A social networking service where the operative question is not “what are you doing?” but “where are you going?”
articles.abstract: A social networking service where the operative question is not “what are you doing?” but “where are you going?”
articles.lead_paragraph: Twitter and Facebook ask users to answer the question: What are you doing right now?

articles.headline: At Book Fair, a Subplot About Chinese Rights
articles.snippet: At the Frankfurt Book Fair, what Beijing hoped would be a celebration of cultural achievements became a tug of war between control and free speech.
articles.abstract: At the Frankfurt Book Fair, what Beijing hoped would be a celebration of cultural achievements became a tug of war between control and free speech.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT  As China extends its economic reach, it has also increased efforts to promote its culture, or “soft power,” to counter Western influence and improve its image in the wider world.
articles.byline: By Steven Erlanger and Jonathan Ansfield

articles.headline: Many Sources Feed Taliban’s War Chest
articles.snippet: Despite efforts by the U.S. and its allies to cripple the Taliban’s sophisticated financial network, American officials say they’ve barely made a dent.
articles.abstract: Despite efforts by the U.S. and its allies to cripple the Taliban’s sophisticated financial network, American officials say they’ve barely made a dent.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Taliban in Afghanistan are running a sophisticated financial network to pay for their insurgent operations, raising hundreds of millions of dollars from the illicit drug trade, kidnappings, extortion and foreign donations that American officials say they are struggling to cut off.

articles.headline: Energy Firms Find No Unity on Climate Bill
articles.snippet: Energy producers are battling over policy decisions worth hundreds of billions of dollars in coming decades.
articles.abstract: Energy producers are battling over policy decisions worth hundreds of billions of dollars in coming decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  As the Senate prepares to tackle global warming, the nation’s energy producers, once united, are battling one another over policy decisions worth hundreds of billions of dollars in coming decades.
articles.byline: By JOHN BRODER and JAD MOUAWAD

articles.headline: Arrest of Hedge Fund Chief Unsettles the Industry
articles.snippet: At the center of the investigation into a purported insider trading ring is Raj Rajaratnam, who rose from a technology analyst to become a hedge fund billionaire.
articles.abstract: At the center of the investigation into a purported insider trading ring is Raj Rajaratnam, who rose from a technology analyst to become a hedge fund billionaire.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, whenever anyone asked Raj Rajaratnam about the success of his hedge fund, the Galleon Group, he chalked it up to being hungrier than everyone else.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Zachery Kouwe

articles.headline: Goodbye Baghdad, Hello Kabul
articles.snippet: For the first time in years, Afghanistan has “emerged as the top story” for news organizations.
articles.abstract: For the first time in years, Afghanistan has “emerged as the top story” for news organizations.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the Obama administration debates whether to send more troops to Afghanistan, a squadron of journalists has already arrived. Many of them are transplants from America’s other overseas war, in Iraq.

articles.headline: Foreclosures Force Ex-Homeowners to Turn to Shelters
articles.snippet: Over the last year, an average of 10 percent of homeless people became so through foreclosure, which was rarely a factor even three years ago.
articles.abstract: Over the last year, an average of 10 percent of homeless people became so through foreclosure, which was rarely a factor even three years ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND  The first night after she surrendered her house to foreclosure, Sheri West endured the darkness in her Hyundai sedan. She parked in her old driveway, with her flower-print dresses and hats piled in boxes on the back seat, and three cherished houseplants on the floor. She used her backyard as a restroom.

articles.headline: Afghan Leader Said to Accept Runoff After Election Audit
articles.snippet: Under heavy international pressure, President Hamid Karzai appears set to concede as early as Tuesday that he fell short of a first-round victory.
articles.abstract: Under heavy international pressure, President Hamid Karzai appears set to concede as early as Tuesday that he fell short of a first-round victory.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan  Under heavy international pressure, President Hamid Karzai appears set to concede as early as Tuesday that he fell short of a first-round victory in the nation’s disputed presidential election, but the path to ensuring that the country has credible leadership remains uncertain, American and European officials said Monday.
articles.byline: By Sabrina Tavernise and Helene Cooper
